title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [21 april–3 may? 1873]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [21 April–3 May? 1873]
text: Spring of 1873walter dearyou didentdidn't write how you was partecularlyparticularly that you was about the same but i want to hear all about if you can walk any better and if your leg is any stronger and if you are well enoughfenough to write any in the office and if you go to the ristorantrestaurant to your meals so dear waltWalt you can answer all or none just as you feel disposedo i think sometimes if i could see mattyMatty once more as i used to and tell her all my ups and downs what a comfort it would be to me i never had any one even my own daughters i could tell every thing to as i could her) when you get old like me waltWalt you feel the need of such a friendgeorge sgeorge's house is progressing they are putting up the brick wall and he is full of business) Lou is come down in the parlor to day her aunt remains here and waits and wontwon't let her hardly move arount i wouldentwouldn't be very sorry if aunty wasentwasn't here but i think she expects to stay a long while)walt if you should have any thing to write to me that you dontdon't want the others to see write it on a small peecepiece of paper as the letter man brings the letters but waltWalt doodo write as often as you cangive my love to mrsMrs. oconorO'Connor and remember me to peterPeter DoylDoylewe saw the news of the modoc massacre last sundaySunday but thought maybeemaybe it wasentwasn't true till we got the herald Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [21 April–3 May? 1873]
